div.p: >> Hi, this is Joyce Farrell.

Let's take a look at
exception handling.

Let's look at a short program
that computes a percent.

For example, you might declare
points earned on a quiz,

points passable for the
entire quiz, and percent,

which is a ratio
between those two values.

When you make these
declarations,

three spots are set
up in memory.

You then might prompt the user
to enter the points earned.

And you might input a four to
the points earned variable.

Then you might prompt
enter points possible.

And suppose the user
types a five.

You'd put five in the
points possible variable.

Then the arithmetic
would consist

of dividing points
earned by points passable,
or four divided by five.
Percent would be point 80.

Then to output it, you
might multiply it by 100,

so the answer would
be percent is 80.
The program would end normally.

Now suppose something
goes wrong.

Suppose when you run the
program, the user puts in a four

for points earned, and it's
stored, and then the user puts

in zero for points
possible, and it's stored.

When you do the arithmetic,
you're dividing four by zero.

In every programming
language, dividing four
by zero is an illegal operation.
An exception is generated.

In object-oriented
programming languages,
programmers call the error

that is generated
an exception object.

And they say that it's thrown
to someplace that can handle it.

This program has indicated no
special place to handle it.

So in this case, the
exception is thrown
to the operating system.

And there, a message
is generated.

The message will be different in
different programming languages.
But basically, it will say

that this is an unhandled
exception, divisioned by zero.

You might choose instead
to handle the exception.

In that case, you can add
a triblock to your program.

A triblock is a block of code
in which you put statements

that might generate
an exception.
You then can add a catch block.

A catch block contains
statements that you want

to have execute if an
exception is generated.

In this example,
in the triblock,

you'd put the arithmetic that
might cause division by zero.

And in the catch block, perhaps
you'd say set the percent
to zero, if that happens.

You could put different
statements here.

You might want to
set the percent
to a different default value.

Or you might want to
re-prompt the user.

You put in the catch block
whatever you want to have happen
if the exception is thrown.

After the triblock
and the catch block,

you can finish the program
and output the results.

So when you run this
program and prompt the user

for points earned, the
user might still type four,
and it will be stored.

And when you say
enter points possible,

the user might still type
zero, and it will be stored.

This time, when you
do the arithmetic,

the exception is
still generated.
But because it's in a triblock,

the exception can be
thrown to a catch block.

So when the exception
goes to the catch block,

the catch block executes, and
the percent is set to zero.

Then the output can be percent
is 0 times 100, or percent is 0.
Let's look at the program again.
Enter points earned, four.
Enter points possible, five.

In this case, when you
get to the triblock,
the points earned divided

by points possible is
a legitimate value.

In this case, the catch block
is bypassed, and you can just go

to output the result,
percent is 80.
Thanks for watching.
